Secondly, even if everyone were on the same page about what quality service was, wouldn't it still be unfair for the hard work of the server to go unrewarded? Imagine a server who was very hardworking, friendly, and efficient and received a 10% tip, or a server who wasn't the best but received a 5%.
If you think tipping is unfair, try working in the service industry.
-November 7th, 2011 at 10:18 AM
Tipping doesn't go with most other things in our society. Doctors can still be great doctors even if they pay $10 for lunch. I don't feel that I should give a "kiss on the cheek" to a waiter.
-June 26th, 2012 at 5:56 AM
As a server, I know the problem is our pay is based on tips. All that matters, to management, is our check total. No matter if you "tip out" our friends well or not at all, we still only get the same base pay. If we all get in and earn the same hourly rate, why should "good" servers be penalized for rewarding people who deserve it, and why should those who don't get rewarded? When you're on the brink of poverty and a 20 dollar tip is actually a few bucks more than a meal, then of course we think that tip is great. But that doesn't mean we should stop being nice. That just means we need a raise. All you have to do is take a simple survey of how great service you received from different servers, even on days we didn't get a lot tipped... And you'll see that we almost always deserve better than the minimum wage most servers get paid here in the state. And if you don't agree, then don't tip us well. We'll get our dues through other means.
-November 20th, 2012 at 1:38 PM. We have to start from the standpoint that servers aren't getting paid enough. We have to decide, as a society, we are going raise their base pay to a living wage, then we get back to tipping, but we get to decide whether we want to pay more (or less). There are all kinds people in the service industry, from those who take great care of our needs, to those who don't. And yes, the person who takes great care of us deserves to get that $20 tip from my friends. But I don't think that anyone should be forcing you (or me) to take care of their friends, family, co-workers at your establishment. That should be the server's decision. Now, if I don't get rewarded with a "gratuity", I deserve to let my friends and family know that there are always better choices. And most servers out there will take care of you, without tipping them. You shouldn't expect to get better service because you're tipping them 20%.
-January 1st, 2013 at 6:34 PM
There has been little push back from the servers towards the tipping system. Why? Because the only people they do know at a "high tip" standard are people they hate/distrust. Why? Because they are always getting "whining" (at best) customers who are constantly pounding (at worst) the server for being inadequate, or worse, being a "lazy" or "selfish" server.
The tip system is designed to pay you less per hour than you would get with a regular wage. That's what makes it so unpopular with the servers. If you think you're getting a "service" that you (their friend) wants to tip more than 10% for (good service) you're just getting ripped off. That's the whole point to me.
-January 30th, 2013 at 11:36 PM
There should be no tip system. If I feel I get good service, I tip more. If I don't feel I'm getting good service, I give no tip.
It's that simple. Period. It's a decision.
-June 6th, 2014 at 3:08 PM
As a server I do all I can and still have to rely on the tipping system to keep my head above water. I've had customers who pay the absolute minimum or 5% when I was doing a great job. It is my job to try to provide excellent service and know that I should be tipped for a job well done. Every person in a position should be tipped for their work. I think everyone should be tipped in the service industry. We are all just trying to make our living and support our families and we deserve for our efforts to be recognised as much as everyone else. But that being said, we are the ones providing the service and getting money and if we did it for free, no one would tip and the system would fall. We provide for a living but we deserve for our work to be recognised as much any other job.
-October 1st, 2017 at 7:45 AM
We are not paid enough at Starbucks and the tips that we receive are not a guarantee. I could have a terrible busy day and I could still only have made around minimum wage, and I could have had a customer who generously tipped for great service. If I never had a bad busy day, I still might not have made minimum wage. I can only try to provide excellent customer service at every time of the day and every customer but no matter what, I cannot guarantee I will be fairly compensated. I also have noticed that sometimes the customer gets the "customer is paying more for better service" approach. I always feel like I'm getting scoffed at and maybe they're getting the best service a barista can provide but don't feel the need to reward me. I've thought about speaking with my manager but then they might give me a bad review because I can't work as many hours as I want.
-November 7th, 2017 at 6:53 AM
I've been a server for 8 years and a college student for 5. I've had some customers that give the tip because they can't live with the waiter not giving good service. I want to earn minimum wage so I tip less most days. I have had more than $50 tips on occasion, in small towns. I can't live on those tips but they are nice. I think tipping is an awesome way to show your appreciation of your server. Sometimes we are bad at our job and then we get a horrible tip. Other times we are great and give you a stellar experience but no tip if you can't appreciate it. I think tipping shouldn't be a requirement and everyone should have the option to tip based on how well we do our job.
-December 3rd, 2019 at 7:16 PM
As a restaurant or server, I don't like tipping. I'd prefer to see some type of raise being given as well as the gratuity being based on actual service. Some people do a great job, some are not too pleasant to deal with regardless of the service. If it was based off of just the service, we would see a lot less complaints then what we currently see.
-August 19th, 2020 at 3:37 PM
I worked at a hospitality business with the intent to use tips for a raise. 6 months in and they've kept my pay static while everyone else got a raise.
This sucks.
-October 7th, 2021 at 8:29 AM
I work in a cafe and I think I make way more money that I should.
-October 7th, 2021 at 8:48 AM
There are actually laws protecting your right to a fair wage as an employee. You don't have to live off tips.
-October 7th, 2021 at 10:55 AM
-November 13th, 2021 at 10:42 PM
I worked as a server for a long time, and I paid taxes off of TIME WAGE.
Honestly, how do you make a living on tips? I'm out of work now so I don't work tipped jobs.
I think you're wrong.
-December 27th, 2021 at 5:17 AM
I'm not in america.
-January 9th, 2023 at 1:01 AM
I used to work in a coffee place as a barista and they didn't have a tipping policy.
But if the customer tips, we get that. But even with tipping, we didn't make very much money.
-January 9th, 2023 at 4:14 PM
I worked at a coffee shop. It wasn't tipping based and the staff got paid a fair hourly rate. Most of the places I've worked at, we get tipped.
-January 9th, 2023 at 11:09 PM
In the US you don't have too much of a choice to get a fair hourly wage.
For a job you don't need to get a raise. It's just expected.
